abstracts.cdata!:
This report judges that overall the
            First Health Project (FHP) was partially successful in
            achieving its objectives (partially successful on improving
            the health status by extending access and improving
            services, less progress was made in enhancing the efficiency
            of service delivery and improving financing prospects, while
            significant progress was made in strengthening Ministry of
            Health (MOH) management capacity). Key lessons learned
            follow. Lack of an independent outside auditor reduced
            project success. A strong policy dialogue, linked to the
            provision of resources, would be more effective than
            resources alone. MOH ability to provide adequate staff must
            be an integral part of a project involving construction of
            new facilities. The project would have benefited from more
            flexibility and the presence in the resident mission of a
            staff member dedicated to support of health projects.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objectives are to
            improve access to basic health services, enhance service
            delivery and strengthen the Ministry of Health's
            management capacity. The project will involve two
            components: (i) the reorganization and expansion of
            provincial health services in ten underserved provinces; and
            (ii) institutional development of the Ministry of Health,
            focussing on training and curriculum development, management
            information systems, and applied studies. Specifically, the
            loan will finance; (i) construction or expansion of
            provincial health facilities and training centers; (ii)
            furniture, equipment and vehicles for the above facilities;
            (iii) technical assistance, overseas and local training, and
            applied research; and (iv) project monitoring and evaluation.
